Alarm Command Class.description: Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS VERSION HAS BEEN DEPRECATED A device MAY implement this Command Class version, but it is RECOMMENDED that new implementations comply with Notification Command Class, version 8 The Alarm Command Class is intended for Z-Wave enabled devices capable of reporting alarm reports. ersion 2 of the Alarm Command Class is improved with the following functionalities: • Alarm Types defined by the Z-Wave Alliance • Interview process of supported Alarm Types The commands not described in this version remain unchanged from Alarm Command Class, version 1 [DEPRECATED].

Alarm Set Command.description: This command is used to set the activity of the Z-Wave Alarm Type and Status.

Alarm Get Command.description: The Alarm Get Command is used to request the alarm state for a specific alarm type announced as supported through the Alarm Type Supported Report Command. The Alarm Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command if the alarm type is supported. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Alarm Report Command.description: This command is used by the application to report the alarm state.

Alarm Type Supported Get Command.description: This command is used to request the supported alarm types. The Alarm Type Supported Report Command MUST be returned in response to an Alarm Type Supported Get command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Alarm Type Supported Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the supported alarm types in the application.

Alarm Sensor Command Class.description:
Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS HAS BEEN DEPRECATED A device MAY implement this command class, but it is RECOMMENDED that new implementations use the Notification Command Class.   
If implementing this Command Class, it is RECOMMENDED that the Notification Command Class is also implemented. The Alarm Sensor Command Class is used to realize Sensor Alarms.

Alarm Sensor Get Command.description: This command is used to request the status of a sensor. The Alarm Sensor Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command if the sensor type is supported. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Alarm Sensor Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the alarm state.

Alarm Sensor Supported Get Command.description: This command is used to request the supported sensor types from the device. The Alarm Sensor Supported Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Alarm Sensor Supported Report Command.description: This command is used to report the supported sensor types from the device.

Alarm Silence Command Class.description: The Alarm Silence Command Class may be used to temporarily disable the sounding of the alarm but still keep the alarm operating.

Alarm Silence Set Command.description: This command is used to remotely silence the sensor alarm.

All Switch Command Class.description: Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS HAS BEEN OBSOLETED New implementations MUST NOT support this Command Class. Controlling nodes MUST use S2 Multicast mechanism in order to achieve the All On and All Off functionality The All Switch Command Class is used to switch all devices on or off. Devices may be excluded/included from the all on/all off functionality. The application determines which devices there are included in the all on/all off functionality as default.

All Switch Set Command.description: This command is used to instruct a device if it is included or excluded from the all on/all off functionality.

All Switch Get Command.description: This command is used to ask a device if it is included or excluded from the all on/all off functionality. The All Switch Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

All Switch Report Command.description: This command is used to report if the device is included or excluded from the all on/all off functionality.

All Switch On Command.description: This command is used to inform a switch that it SHOULD be turned on. A receiving device MUST NOT react to this command if the actual operation has been prohibited via the Switch All Set command. Like the Basic Set On command, this command MUST cause the device to restore the most recent (non-zero) level.

All Switch Off Command.description: This command is used to inform a switch that it SHOULD be turned off. A receiving device MUST NOT react to this command if the actual operation has been prohibited via the Switch All Set command.

Anti-theft Command Class.description: This Command Class is used to lock (and possibly unlock) a node.

Anti-Theft Set Command.description: This command is used to lock or unlock a node.

Anti-theft Get Command.description: This command is used to request the locked/unlocked state of a supporting node. The Anti-Theft Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Anti-Theft Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the lock/unlock state of a supporting node.

Anti-theft Unlock Command Class.description: This Command Class is used to unlock a device that has been locked by the Anti-theft Command Class. Controllers that do not lock devices still can control this command class in order to unlock devices that have been locked by previous owners.

Anti-Theft Unlock State Get Command.description: This command is used to request the locked/unlocked state of the node. The Anti-Theft Unlock State Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Anti-Theft Unlock State Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the current locked/unlocked state of the node with some additional information.

Anti-Theft Unlock Set Command.description: This command is used to unlock a node that is currently locked. A receiving node MUST ignore this command if its current state is unlocked.

Authentication Command Class.description: Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS HAS NEVER BEEN CERTIFIED This command class has never been implemented and certified by a Z-Wave product Therefore, this Command Class definition MAY be updated in a non-backwards compatible manner, or even removed. Consult with the Z-Wave Alliance Application Work Group if you consider implementing this Command Class. Authentication Command Class is a generic Command Class which can be used for transporting different technology authentication data contents (e.g., RFID, Magnetic Cards, etc.) in a Z-Wave network for access control systems.

Authentication Capability Get Command.description: This command is used to request the Authentication technology capabilities, number of Authentication ID and Data ID supported by the receiving node. The Authentication Capability Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Authentication Capability Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the Authentication Command Class capabilities of sending node.

Authentication Data Set Command.description: This command is used to define Authentication Data for a given Data Identifier at the receiving node.

Authentication Data Get Command.description: This command is used to request the Authentication Data defined for a given Authentication Data ID. The Authentication Data Report MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Authentication Data Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the Authentication Data assigned at the supporting node for a given Authentication Data ID entry.

Authentication Technologies Combination.description: This command is used to define the Combination Entries at the receiving node.

This command is used for requesting defined combination entries of a specific Authentication ID. The Authentication Technologies Combination Report MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.
This command is used to advertise defined Combination Entries of a specific Authentication ID.

Authentication Checksum Get Command.description: This command is used to request checksum(s) representing the current authentication data or combinations set at the supporting node. A supporting node MUST return a response with the Checksum field set to 0x00 if the checksum type or the authentication type is not supported. The Authentication Checksum Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Authentication Checksum Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the checksum representing current authentication data that correspond to a specific technology type or combination entries defined at the supporting node

Authentication Media Write Command Class.description: Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS HAS NEVER BEEN CERTIFIED This command class has never been implemented and certified by a Z-Wave product Therefore, this Command Class definition MAY be updated in a non-backwards compatible manner, or even removed. Consult with the Z-Wave Alliance Application Work Group if you consider implementing this Command Class. This command class is used to write raw Authentication Media data, such as RFID data contents on tags. The supported authentication medium itself is specific to individual nodes. Supporting nodes can use the Entry Control Command Class to report the corresponding readings of their supported Authentication Media.

Authentication Media Capability Get Comm.description: This command is used to request the Authentication Media capabilities supported by the receiving node. The Authentication Media Capability Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Authentication Media Capability Report C.description: This command is used to advertise the Authentication Media Command Class capabilities supported by the sending node.

Authentication Media Write Start Command.description: This command is used to write Authentication Media contents (i.e., RFID data to a tag). The Authentication Media Write Status Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Authentication Media Write Stop Command.description: This command is used to interrupt an ongoing Authentication Media Write operation. The Authentication Media Write Status Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Authentication Media Write Status Comman.description: This command is used to advertise the status of an Authentication Media Write operation.

Barrier Operator Command Class.description: The Barrier Operator Command Class is used to control and query the status of motorized barriers.

Barrier Operator Set Command.description: This command is used to initiate an unattended change in state of the barrier. A supporting node MAY ignore this command if the requested operation violates operational limitations or safety regulations.

Barrier Operator Get Command.description: This command is used to request the current state of a barrier operator device. The Barrier Operator Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Barrier Operator Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the status of the barrier operator device.

Barrier Operator Get Signaling Capabilit.description: This command is used to query a device for available subsystems which may be controlled via Z-Wave. The Barrier Operator Report Signaling Capabilities Supported Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Barrier Operator Report Signaling Capabi.description: This command returns a bit mask of signaling subsystem(s) supported by the sending node. The device that issuing this command may not support any signaling subsystem(s).

Barrier Operator Event Signal Set Comman.description: This command is used to turn on or off an event signaling subsystem that is supported by the device. A supporting node MAY ignore this command if the requested operation violates safety regulations. UL requirements MUST take precedence over any Set command sent to a subsystem. It is up to the discretion of the device to accept or reject the requested action. If the requested action is rejected, the node MUST notify the requester via the Notification Command Class Report with the Notification {Access Control::Barrier unable to perform requested operation due to UL requirements}. Subsystem Type (8 bits) This field is used to indicate which subsystem type MUST be set at the receiving node. This field MUST comply with Table 2.76.

Barrier Operator Event Signaling Get Com.description: This command is used to request the state of a signaling subsystem to a supporting node. The Barrier Operator Event Signaling Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command if the specified type is supported. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Barrier Operator Event Signaling Report.description: This command is used to indicate the state of a notification subsystem of a Barrier Device.

Basic Command Class.description: The Basic Command Class allows a controlling device to operate the primary functionality of another device without any further knowledge. The Basic Command Class ensures a basic interoperability if no other Command Class is shared by two devices. The Basic Command Class is an actuator control command class. Refer to Section 2.1.6.

Basic Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the status of the primary functionality of the device.

Basic Tariff Information Command Class.description: Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS HAS NEVER BEEN CERTIFIED This command class has never been implemented and certified by a Z-Wave product Therefore, this Command Class definition MAY be updated in a non-backwards compatible manner, or even removed. Consult with the Z-Wave Alliance Application Work Group if you consider implementing this Command Class. This Basic Tariff Information Command Class for use with a single element or dual element meter, and for use with import (electricity received from grid) rates only. The command class is kept as simple as possible without any pricing information. This command class supports a GET and REPORT. No Set command is supported, as it is not appropriate to set any of the parameters through Z-Wave.

Basic Tariff Information Get Command.description: This command is used to request current tariff information from the meter. The Basic Tariff Information Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Basic Tariff Information Report Command.description: This command returns information on the number of import rates supported, and current import rate information. Application can send unsolicited Basic Tariff Report commands or requested by the Basic Tariff Get Information command.

Basic Window Covering Command Class.description: Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS HAS BEEN OBSOLETED New implementations MUST NOT support this command class. New window covering device implementations SHOULD support the Window Covering Command Class, version 1. This section contains Commands that may be used to control a Basic Window Covering Command Class.

Basic Window Covering Start Level Change.description: This command is used to start moving drapes, shades, blinds in a given direction. The speed of the movement is implementation specific. Open/Close (1 bit) If the Open/Close bit is set to 0 the window covering SHOULD open. If field is set to 1 the window covering SHOULD close.

Basic Window Covering Stop Level Change.description: This command is used to stop moving drapes, shades, blinds in a given direction.

Binary Sensor Command Class.description:
Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS HAS BEEN DEPRECATED A device MAY implement this command class, but it is RECOMMENDED that new implementations use the Notification Command Class, version 3-8. If implementing this command class, it is RECOMMENDED that the Notification Command Class, version 3-8 is also implemented. The Binary Sensor Command Class is used to realize binary sensors, such as movement sensors and door/window sensors. Version 2 of this command class is extended with the following functionalities: • A “get-supported” mechanism for the controlling device to interview the binary sensor for its supported sensor types   
• A list of defined sensor types capable of reporting a binary value NOTE: A binary sensor is defined as a sensor unit capable of providing a binary value in the report i.e. that an event was “triggered” or “not triggered” and not other intermediate values. For sensor units providing multiple values the Multilevel Sensor Command Class is more suitable. The Binary Sensor Command Class can further advance through implementation of the Notification Command Class to communicate details about the event.

Binary Sensor Get Command.description: This command is used to request the status of the specific sensor device. The Binary Sensor Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Binary Sensor Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise a sensor value.

Binary Sensor Get Supported Sensor Comma.description: This command is used to request the supported sensor types from the binary sensor device.

Binary Sensor Supported Sensor Report Co.description: This command must be sent as requested by a received Binary Sensor Get Supported Sensor Command. This command indicates the supported sensor types of the binary sensor device in a bit mask format and MUST NOT be transmitted unsolicited.

Binary Switch Command Class.description:
The Binary Switch Command Class is used to control the On/Off state of supporting nodes.   
The Binary Switch Command Class is an actuator control Command Class. Refer to Section 2.1.6.

Binary Switch Set Command.description: This command is used to set the binary state at the receiving node.

Binary Switch Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the current On/Off state at the sending node.

Binary Toggle Switch Command Class.description: The Binary Toggle Switch Command Class is used for toggle-style control of binary actuator devices.

Binary Toggle Switch Set Command.description: This command is used to toggle a device e.g. from on to off and from off to on.

Binary Toggle Switch Get Command.description: This command is used to request the state of the load controlled by the device. The Binary Toggle Switch Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Binary Toggle Switch Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the value of a toggle switch.

Central Scene Command Class.description: The Central Scene Command Class, version 3 extends version 2 by adding a new mode for the transmission of Key Held Down notifications. This allows a node to send Key Held Down refreshes at a low rate for the duration of the key held down. The purpose of this new feature is to provide improved compatibility with FLiRS beaming and network routing. Central Scene Command Class, version 3 introduces three new commands to allow a controller to query and configure node capabilities. • Central Scene Configuration Set Command • Central Scene Configuration Get Command • Central Scene Configuration Report Command Central Scene Command Class, version 3 extends the following commands for a scene launching node to advertise its optional capabilities. • Central Scene Supported Report Command • Central Scene Notification Command

Central Scene Configuration Set Command.description: This command is used to configure the use of optional node capabilities for scene notifications.

Central Scene Configuration Get Command.description: This command is used to query the configuration of optional node capabilities for scene notifications. .05.11.001 The Central Scene Configuration Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Central Scene Configuration Report Comma.description: This command is used to advertise the configuration of optional node capabilities for scene notifications.

Central Scene Supported Get Command.description: This command is used to request the maximum number of scenes that this device supports. .11.001 The Central Scene Supported Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Central Scene Supported Report Command.description: This command is used to report the maximum number of supported scenes and the Key Attributes supported for each scene. All fields not described below are the same as in version 2.

Central Scene Notification Command.description: This command is used to advertise a key event. 001 If the device implements Z-Wave Plus Lifeline support, the device MUST send the Central Scene Notification Command to the actual Lifeline targets. All fields not described below are the same as in version 2.

Climate Control Schedule Command Class.description: Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS HAS BEEN DEPRECATED A device MAY implement this command class, but it is RECOMMENDED that new implementations use the Schedule Command Class, version 1. If implementing this command class, it is RECOMMENDED that the Schedule Command Class, version 1 is also implemented. The Climate Control Schedule Command Class allows devices to exchange schedules and overrides, which specify when to perform a setback on the setpoint. Note: The setpoint is the temperature a device will try to maintain. The setback is a deviation from the setpoint. When a setback is in use the device will apply the setback to the setpoint, resulting in a different temperature. When using schedules and overrides it is possible to define several setbacks occurring at specific times. Schedules are exchanged using the Schedule Commands. Overrides of schedules are exchanged using the Schedule Override Commands. Detection of updated schedules is done using the Schedule Changed Commands. The Climate Control Schedule uses the Schedule State type to define each setback. The Schedule State type has the following format:

Schedule Set Command.description: This command is used to set the climate control schedule in a device for a specific weekday. A climate control schedule defines when to use a setback on the setpoint in a device. A schedule can hold a maximum of 9 switchpoints. A switchpoint defines one setback from the current setpoint. The entire list of switchpoints in the Command MUST be ordered by time, ascending from 00:00 towards 23:59. Switchpoints which have a Schedule State set to “Unused” MUST be placed last. Duplicates MUST NOT be allowed for Switchpoints which have a Schedule State different from “Unused”.

Schedule Get Command.description: This command is used to request the climate control schedule in a device for a specific weekday. The Schedule Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods. For fields’ description, refer to Section 2.2.25.1 Schedule Set Command.

Schedule Report Command.description: This command is used to report the climate control schedule in a device for a specific weekday.

Schedule Changed Get Command.description: This command is used to check if the climate control schedule has changed. The Schedule Changed Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Schedule Changed Report Command.description: This command is used to report if the climate control schedule has changed.

Schedule Override Set Command.description: This command is used to set the override in a device. The purpose of an override is to inform a device to ignore its current climate control schedule and assume the setting provided by the Override Type and Override State fields.

Schedule Override Get Command.description: This command is used to request the override, currently in use in a device. The Schedule Override Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Schedule Override Report Command.description: The Schedule Override Report Command is used to report the override, currently in use in a device.

Clock Command Class.description: The Clock Command Class is used to implement a simple clock functionality.

Clock Set Command.description: This command is used to set the current time in a supporting node.

Clock Get Command.description: This command is used to request the current time set at a supporting node. The Clock Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Clock Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the current time set at the sending node. For fields’ description, refer to Clock Set Command A sending node MUST comply with fields’ description from Clock Set Command

Color Switch Command Class.description: The Color Switch Command Class is used to control color capable devices. The Color Switch Command Class manipulates the color components of a device. Each color component is scaled by the brightness level previously set by a Multilevel Switch Set or Basic Set command. The Color Switch Command Class is an actuator control command class. Refer to Section 2.1.6.

Color Switch Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the status of a color component.

Color Switch Start Level Change Command.description: This command is used to initiate a transition of one color component to a new value.

Configuration Command Class.description: The Configuration Command Class, version 4 introduces the support of read-only parameters, parameters requiring network re-inclusion and advanced parameters as well as allows optional support for Bulk Commands. A read-only parameter can be accessed with Get commands but cannot be modified with Set Commands. A parameter requiring re-inclusion is typically a parameter altering the node capabilities, which requires performing the inclusion again in order to have the controller to learn about the node capabilities once more. A parameter may be advertised as “advanced” to indicate to the controlling application that the actual parameter is intended only for advanced use, e.g. calibration. The following commands are modified in version 4: • Configuration Set Command • Configuration Bulk Set Command • Configuration Properties Report Command The following new command is introduced: • Configuration Default Reset Command All commands not mentioned in this version remain unchanged from previous versions.

Configuration Set Command.description: This command is used to set the value of a configuration parameter. A receiving node MUST ignore this command if the specified parameter is advertised as a Read-only parameter. All fields not specified below are unchanged from version 2 Configuration Set Command.

Configuration Bulk Set Command.description: This command is used to set the value of one or more configuration parameters. A receiving node MUST ignore this command for parameters that are advertised as Read-only parameters. All fields not specified below are unchanged from version 2 Configuration Bulk Set Command.

Configuration Properties Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the properties of a configuration parameter. All fields not specified below are unchanged from version 3 Configuration Properties Report Command.

Configuration Default Reset Command.description: This command is used to reset all configuration parameters to their default value. 70.04.01.11.001 A node receiving this command MUST reset all its Configuration Parameters to their default value

Controller Replication Command Class.description: The Controller Replication Command Class is used to copy scene and group data to another controlling node. The Command Class may be used in conjunction with a controller shift or when including a new controller to the network. It is OPTIONAL to use this command class during a controller shift or when including a new controller to the network.

Transfer group command.description: This command is used to replicate mappings between Group ID and Node ID.

Transfer Group Name Command.description: This command is used to replicate group names.

Transfer scene command.description: This command is used to replicate mappings between Scene ID and Node ID.

Transfer Scene Name Command.description: This command is used to replicate scene names.

Demand Control Plan Configuration Comman.description: The Demand Control Plan Configuration Command Class allows Utility Suppliers to issue and manage a list of Demand Control Plan (DCP) events to the end consumer. The DCP Configuration commands are separated for the DCP monitoring commands in the Demand Control Plan Monitor Command Class, allowing the classes to be optionally supported at different security levels. (E.g. DCP monitoring commands could be supported using non-secure communication, while enabling strict secure-only communication for the DCP Configuration Command Class). Refer to the Security and Security 2 command classes for more details. A DCP event contains information regarding criticality, products involved, requested reduction, time duration and if a certain rate (identified by a Demand Control Plan Rate ID, refer to the Rate Table Configuration Command Class) is associated with the event. When a DCP event is outdated, it is removed from the list. It is the utility supplier responsibility to prevent overflow of the list by query the number of free positions in the list before submitting a new DCP event to the list. Each DCP event is uniquely identified by a timestamp issued the Utility Supplier. A DCP event may also include information, which enables devices not supporting this class to use in the Demand Control Plan through the Start & Stop Association Group functionality. The installer, the end user or Utility Supplier (remote management) configures the Association groups. During the configuration process the devices are selected and the association entries are created. These associations can additionally be configured with the specific Z-Wave commands (through the Association Command Configuration Command Class). If no Z-Wave commands are specified in the Associations groups, it is the responsibility of the device to issue the relevant commands based on Utility Supplier specific algorithms.

DCP list supported get command.description: This command is used to request the total size of the DCP list along with the number of free entries in the list. The DCP List Supported Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

DCP list supported report command.description: This command is used to provide the total size of the DCP list along with the number of free entries in the list.

DCP list set command.description: This command is used to place a new DCP event in the DCP list. Each DCP event is time stamped for future reference.

Demand Control Plan Monitor Command Clas.description: The Demand Control Plan Monitor Command Class allows devices to monitor the list of Demand Control Plan (DCP). A DCP event contains information regarding criticality, products involved, requested reduction, time duration and if a certain rate (identified by a Demand Control Plan Rate ID, refer to the Rate Table Configuration Command Class) is associated with the event. When a DCP event is outdated, it is removed from the list. Each DCP event is uniquely identified by a timestamp issued the Utility Supplier.

DCP list get command.description: This command is used to request the pending DCP event in a device. The DCP List Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

DCP list report command.description: This command reports the pending DCP event in a device. If more than one DCP event is pending - the reports will be submitted in chronically order as to when the events was placed on the list. Newest entry will be reported first. continues on next page

DCP event status get.description: This command is used to query the status of a specific DCP event in the DCP list. The DCP Event Status Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods. Refer to DCP List Set command class (DCP list set command) for detailed description of the fields.

DCP event status report.description: This command is used to provide the status of a specific DCP event in the DCP list. Refer to DCP List report command class (DCP list report command) for description of fields Event Status (8 bits) The field contains the status of the event. All other values are reserved and MUST NOT be used by a sending node. Reserved values MUST be ignored by a receiving node.

Door Lock Operation Set Command.description: This command is used to set the mode of a supporting door lock node.

Door Lock Operation Get Command.description: This command is used to request the mode of a supporting door lock node. The Door Lock Operation Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Door Lock Operation Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the mode of a supporting door lock node.

Door Lock Configuration Set Command.description: This command is used to set the configuration of a supporting door lock node. A supporting node MUST be able to operate with the factory default configuration.

Door Lock Configuration Get Command.description: This command is used to request the configuration parameters of a door lock device. The Door Lock Configuration Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Door Lock Configuration Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the configuration parameters of a door lock device. Fields not described below MUST be according to descriptions in Section 2.2.39.6 Door Lock Configuration Set Command.

Door Lock Capabilities Get Command.description: This command is used to request the Door Lock capabilities of a supporting node. The Door Lock Capabilities Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Door Lock Capabilities Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the Door Lock capabilities supported by the sending node.

Door Lock Logging Command Class.description:
This Door Lock Logging Command Class provides an audit trail in an access control application.   
Each time an event takes place at the door lock, the system logs the user’s ID, date, time etc.

Door Lock Logging Records Supported Get.description: This command is used to request the number of records that the audit trail supports. The Door Lock Logging Records Supported Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Door Lock Logging Records Supported Repo.description: This command is used to report the maximum number of reports the audit trail supports.

Door Lock Logging Record Get Command.description: This command is used to request the audit trail. The Door Lock Logging Record Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Door Lock Logging Record Report Command.description: This command returns records from the audit trail. To provide flexibility the user associated with the record may be identified by one of two methods: the user identifier or the user code.

Energy Production Command Class.description: Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS HAS NEVER BEEN CERTIFIED This command class has never been implemented and certified by a Z-Wave product Therefore, this Command Class definition MAY be updated in a non-backwards compatible manner, or even removed. Consult with the Z-Wave Alliance Application Work Group if you consider implementing this Command Class. The Energy Production Command Class is used to retrieve various production data from the device.

Energy Production Get Command.description: This command is used to request various production data from the device. The Energy Production Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Energy Production Report Command.description: This command is used to retrieve various production data from the device.

Entry Control Command Class.description:
The Entry Control Command Class defines a method for advertising user input to a central Entry Control application and for the discovery of capabilities. User input may be button presses, RFID tags or other means. It is RECOMMENDED that this command class is only supported via secure communication. This recommendation may be raised to a stronger requirement at the Device Class or Device Type level. The Entry Control Command Class provides the following commands: • Key Supported Get/Report - Used by the controller to request which ASCII keys are present on the Entry Control device.   
• Event Supported Get/Report - Used by the controller to request which Event Types are supported by the Entry Control device.   
• Configuration Set/Get/Report - Used by the controller to configure the Entry Control device   
• Notification Command - Used by the Entry Control device to notify the controller of inputs.

Entry Control Notification Command.description: This command is used to advertise user input. Depending on the Event Type, this command MAY carry manually entered user credentials.

Entry Control Key Supported Get Command.description: This command is used to query the keys that a device implements for entry of user credentials. The Entry Control Key Supported Report command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Entry Control Key Supported Report Comma.description: This command is used to advertise the keys that a device implements for entry of user credentials. A management interface may determine the available keys for credential entry from this command. The range of available Command Keys may be determined via the Entry Control Event Supported Report Command.

Entry Control Event Supported Get Comman.description: This command is used to request the supported Events of a device. The Entry Control Event Supported Report command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Entry Control Configuration Set Command.description: This command is used to configure Event Type specific parameters. Key Cache Size (1 byte) This field specifies the number of characters the key cache MUST store before sending data to the central control application. Data MUST be sent when the number of characters in the cache matches or exceeds the value of this field. The value MUST be in the range 1..32. The default value of this field SHOULD be 4. In deployments where characters are entered first and a command button is pressed subsequently, it is RECOMMENDED that this field is set to 32 and that the Key Cache Timeout is set to 2 seconds.

Entry Control Configuration Get Command.description: This command is used to request the operational mode of a device. The Entry Control Configuration Report command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Entry Control Configuration Report Comma.description: This command is used to advertise the current operational mode of a device.

Generic Schedule Command Class.description: Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS HAS NEVER BEEN CERTIFIED This command class has never been implemented and certified by a Z-Wave product Therefore, this Command Class definition MAY be updated in a non-backwards compatible manner, or even removed. Consult with the Z-Wave Alliance Application Work Group if you consider implementing this Command Class. The Generic Schedule Command Class is used to define schedules. Schedules defined in this command class are essentially time ranges or intervals. Each schedule is associated to a Schedule ID. The Schedules defined in this Command Class can be used in other Command Classes, e.g. to schedule when user credentials are valid or when to apply a particular configuration.

Generic Schedule Capabilities Get Comman.description: This command is used to request the scheduling capabilities of a supporting node. The Generic Schedule Capabilities Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Generic Schedule Capabilities Report Com.description: This command is used to advertise the number of supported Schedule Slot IDs for each Schedule Type/User Identifier by the sending node.

Generic Schedule Time Range Set Command.description:
This command is used to configure a Time Range for a supporting node. A Time Range MUST be active when all the conditions indicated in its configuration are fulfilled.   
Some examples are provided in Section 2.2.43.5.1.

Generic Schedule Time Range Get Command.description: This command is used to request the configuration of a Time Range ID for a supporting node. The Generic Schedule Time Range Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Generic Schedule Time Range Report Comma.description: This command is used to advertise the configuration of a Time Range ID for a supporting node. Fields not described below MUST remain identical to the description in Section 2.2.43.5 Generic Schedule Time Range Set Command.

Generic Schedule Set Command.description: This command is used to configure a Schedule for a supporting node. A schedule MUST be active when: • At least one of the included Time Ranges is active • None of the excluded Time Ranges are active. Refer to Section 2.2.43.8.1 for details.

Generic Schedule Get Command.description: This command is used to request the configuration of a Schedule ID for a supporting node. The Generic Schedule Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Generic Schedule Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the contents of a Schedule for a supporting node. Fields not described below MUST remain identical to the description in Section 2.2.43.10.

Geographic LocationCommand Class.description: The Geographic Location Command Class is used to read latitude and longitude from another device. The latitude and longitude may also be set according to the geographic location in question. Date and geographic location may be used to calculate sunrise and sunset for e.g. automatic lighting control.

Geographic Location Set Command.description: This command is used to set latitude and longitude.

Geographic Location Get Command.description: This command is used to request latitude and longitude from a device. The Geographic Location Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Geographic Location Report Command.description: This command returns latitude and longitude from a device in a Z-Wave network. Refer to description under the Geographic Location Set Command.

HRV Status Command Class.description: The residential Heat Recovery Ventilation (HRV) Status Command Class is used to read out a number of parameters in the ventilation system.

HRV Status Get Command.description: This command is used to request specific parameters from the ventilation system. The HRV Status Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

HRV Status Report Command.description: This command is used to report a specific status parameter in response to a HRV Status Get.

HRV Status Supported Get Command.description: This command is used to request a bitmap of the supported status parameters. The HRV Status Supported Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

HRV Status Supported Report Command.description: This command is used to report a bitmap indicating the supported status parameters.

HRV Control Command Class.description: The Heat Recovery Ventilation (HRV) Control Command Class is introducing control of Heat Recovery Ventilation systems via the Z-Wave interface.

HRV Mode Set Command.description: This command is used to set the desired mode in the device.

HRV Mode Get Command.description: This command is used to request the current mode from the device. The HRV Mode Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

HRV Mode Report Command.description: The HRV Mode Report Command is used to report the mode from the device.

HRV Bypass Set Command.description: This command is used to set the bypass mode when the ventilation system is set to manual mode. If the system is not in manual mode while receiving this command it MUST be ignored.

HRV Bypass Get Command.description: This command is used to request the current bypass setting. The HRV Bypass Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

HRV Bypass Report Command.description: This command is used to report the current bypass parameters.

HRV Ventilation Rate Set Command.description:
This command is used to set the ventilation rate when the ventilation system is set to manual mode.   
If the system is not in manual mode while receiving this command it MUST be ignored.

HRV Ventilation Rate Get Command.description: This command is used to request the current ventilation rate setting. The HRV Ventilation Rate Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

HRV Ventilation Rate Report Command.description: This command is used to report the current ventilation rate setting.

HRV Mode Supported Get Command.description: This command is used to request the supported modes from the device. The HRV Mode Supported Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

HRV Mode Supported Report Command.description: This command is used to report the supported modes from the device.

Humidity Control Operating State Class.description: The Humidity Control Operating State Command Class is used to obtain the operating state of the humidity control device.

Humidity Control Operating State Get Com.description: This command is used to request the operating state of the humidity control device. The Humidity Control Operating State Report Command MUST be returned in response to thiscommand. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Humidity Control Operating State Report.description: This command is used to report the operating state of the humidity control device.

Humidity Control Setpoint Command Class.description: The Humidity Control Setpoint Command Class is used for humidity control setpoint handling.

Humidity Control Setpoint Set Command.description: This command is used to set the humidity control setpoint in the device.

Humidity Control Setpoint Get Command.description: This command is used to request the given humidity control setpoint type in a device. The Humidity Control Setpoint Report MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Humidity Control Setpoint Report Command.description: This command is used to report the value of the humidity control setpoint type in the device.

Humidity Control Setpoint Supported Get.description: This command is used to request the humidity control setpoint types supported by the device. The Humidity Control Setpoint Supported Report Command MUST be returned in response to a this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Humidity Control Setpoint Supported Repo.description: This command is used to report the humidity control setpoint types supported by the device.

Humidity Control Setpoint Scale Supporte.description: This command is used to retrieve the supported scales of the humidity control setpoints in the device. The Humidity Control Scale Supported Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command.
This command indicates the supported scales of the humidity control setpoint in a bit mask format.

Humidity Control Setpoint Capabilities G.description: This command is used to request the minimum and maximum setpoint values for a given humidity control Setpoint Type. The Humidity Control Setpoint Capabilities Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Humidity Control Setpoint Capabilities R.description: This command is used to report the minimum and maximum values of the requested humidity control setpoint type. Refer to the description under Section 2.2.49.1 Humidity Control Setpoint Set Command for other parameter/field descriptions.

IR Repeater Command Class.description: The IR Repeater Command Class is used to get supporting nodes to learn and/or repeat IR signals used to control appliances. A supporting node MUST have the capability to issue or receive IR signals.

IR Repeater Capabilities Get Command.description: This command is used to request the IR Repeater capabilities of a node. The IR Repeater Capabilities Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

IR Repeater Capabilities Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the IR Repeater capabilities of the sending node.

IR Repeater IR Code Learning Start Comma.description: This command is used to instruct a supporting node to start learning an IR Code. This command MUST be ignored by a receiving node if it advertises 0 Number of IR Code identifiers for learning in the IR Repeater Capabilities Report Command. A supporting node MUST stop learning IR Code and return a IR Repeater IR Code Learning Status Command a when a code has been received/learnt. This command MUST be ignored if the supporting node is already learning an IR code.

IR Repeater IR Code Learning Stop Comman.description: This command is used to instruct a supporting node to stop learning an IR Code. This command MUST be ignored by a receiving node if it advertises 0 Number of IR Code identifiers for learning in the IR Repeater Capabilities Report Command. A supporting node MUST stop learning IR Code if a learning process was ongoing when this command is received. A supporting node MUST return a IR Repeater IR Code Learning Status Command in response to this command.

IR Repeater IR Code Learning Status Comm.description: This command is used to report the status of the last IR Code learning operation. It MUST be issued by a supporting node when it stops learning IR Codes.

IR Repeater Learnt IR Code Remove Comman.description: This command is used to instruct a supporting node to erase a previously learnt an IR Code. This command MUST be ignored by a receiving node if it advertises 0 Number of IR Code identifiers for learning in the IR Repeater Capabilities Report Command.

IR Repeater Learnt IR Code Get Command.description: This command is used to request a supporting node which IR Code identifiers have a valid IR Code learnt. This command MUST be ignored by a receiving node if it advertises 0 Number of IR Code identifiers for learning in the IR Repeater Capabilities Report Command. The IR Repeater Learnt IR Code Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command if it was not ignored. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

IR Repeater Learnt IR Code Report Comman.description: This command is used to advertise the current IR learnt code stored at the supporting node.

IR Repeater Learnt IR Code Readback Get.description: This command is used to request a supporting node has learnt an IR Code to return the code details to a controlling node. This command MUST be ignored by a receiving node if it advertises no support for LCR (Learnt Code Readback) in the IR Repeater Capabilities Report Command. The IR Repeater Learnt IR Code Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command if it was not ignored. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

IR Repeater Learnt IR Code Readback Repo.description: This command is used to advertise the “contents” of a Learn IR Code.

IR Repeater Configuration Set Command.description: This command is used to configure the IR signal properties before the supporting node would repeat IR Codes. This command MUST be ignored by a receiving node if it advertises no support for Bit Encoding Support (BES) in the IR Repeater Capabilities Report Command. A supporting node MUST have a default bit 1, bit 0 and period configured after reset.

IR Repeater Configuration Get Command.description: This command is used to request the IR signal configuration at the supporting node. The IR Repeater Configuration Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST be ignored by a receiving node if it advertises no support for Bit Encoding Support (BES) in the IR Repeater Capabilities Report Command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

IR Repeater Configuration Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the current IR signal repeating configuration at the supporting node.

IR Repeater Repeat Learnt Code Command.description: This command is used to request the receiving node to send an IR Code.

IR Repeater Repeat Command.description: This command is used to request the receiving node to send/repeat an IR Code. This command MUST be ignored if the supporting node advertises no support for IR Code Repeating (IRR) in the IR Repeater Capabilities Report Command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Irrigation Command Class.description: The Irrigation Command Class provides commands to manage irrigation systems.

Irrigation System Info Get Command.description: This command is used to request a receiving node about its irrigation system information. The Irrigation System Info Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Irrigation System Info Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise irrigation system information.

Irrigation System Status Get Command.description: This command is used to request a receiving node about its irrigation system status. The Irrigation System Status Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Irrigation System Status Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise irrigation system status.

Irrigation System Config Set Command.description: This command allows the irrigation system to be configured accordingly.

Irrigation System Config Get Command.description: This command is used to request a receiving node about its current irrigation system configuration. The Irrigation System Config Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Irrigation System Config Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the current irrigation system configuration. For fields’ description, refer to Section 2.2.51.8 Irrigation System Config Set Command. A sending node MUST comply with field descriptions in Section 2.2.51.8 Irrigation System Config Set Command.

Irrigation Valve Info Get Command.description: This command is used to request general information about the specified valve. The Irrigation Valve Info Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Irrigation Valve Info Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise general information about a given valve.

Irrigation Valve Config Set Command.description: This command allows an irrigation valve to be configured accordingly.

Irrigation Valve Config Get Command.description: This command is used to request the current configuration of an irrigation valve. The Irrigation Valve Config Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Irrigation Valve Config Report Command.description: This command is used to advertise the configuration of a valve. A sending node MUST comply with field descriptions in Section 2.2.51.13 Irrigation Valve Config Set Command.

Irrigation Valve Run Command.description: The Irrigation Valve Run Command will run the specified valve for a specified duration.

Irrigation Valve Table Set Command.description: This command is used to set a valve table with a list of valves and durations.

Irrigation Valve Table Get Command.description: This command is used to request the contents of the specified Valve Table ID. The Irrigation Valve Table Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Irrigation Valve Table Report Command.description: This command provides the contents of the specified Valve Table ID. For fields’ description, refer to Section 2.2.51.17 Irrigation Valve Table Set Command. A sending node MUST comply with field descriptions in Section 2.2.51.17 Irrigation Valve Table Set Command.

Irrigation Valve Table Run Command.description: This command is used to run the specified valve tables sequentially.

Irrigation System Shutoff Command.description: This command is used to prevent any irrigation activity triggered by the Schedule CC for a specified duration.

Language Command Class.description: The Language Command Class is used to specify the language settings on a device.

Language Set Command.description: This command is used to set the language at the receiving node. The receiving node SHOULD use the default language in case the received language is not supported.

Language Get Command.description: This command is used to request the current language setting in a device. The Language Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Language Report Command.description: This command returns the current language setting in a device. For fields’ description, refer to Section 2.2.52.1 Language Set Command.

Lock Command Class.description:
Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS HAS BEEN DEPRECATED A device MAY implement this command class, but it is RECOMMENDED that new implementations use the Door Lock Command Class.   
If implementing this command class, it is RECOMMENDED that the Door Lock Command Class is also implemented. The Lock Command Class is used to lock and unlock a “lock” type device, e.g. a door or window lock

Lock Set Command.description: This command is used to set the lock state in a device.

Lock Get Command.description: This command is used to request the lock state from a device. The Lock Report Command MUST be returned in response to this command. This command MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing. A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if this command is received via multicast addressing. The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

Lock Report Command.description: This command is used to report the lock state of a device.

Manufacturer Proprietary Command Class.description: Warning: THIS COMMAND CLASS HAS BEEN OBSOLETED New implementations MUST NOT support this Command Class. Consult the Z-Wave Alliance when your application does not seem to fit any existing Command Class. The Manufacturer Proprietary Command Class is used to transfer data between devices in the Z-Wave network. The data content MUST be vendor specific and MUST be non-value added with respect to the Home Automation application in general. An example could be data used to diagnose the hardware in a device. Note: Do not use the Manufacturer Proprietary Command Class without written approval from the Z-Wave Alliance.

Manufacturer Proprietary Command.description: This command is used to transfer proprietary commands between devices. The Command features a manufacturer specific identifier to allow the receiving device to check if this Command can be interpreted. The vendor is responsible for establishing a Command structure to differ between the set of Commands supported. In order not to congest the Z-Wave network, large data transfers MUST leave transmit opportunities for other nodes in the network. If sending a command longer than two frames, a node MUST implement a delay between every transmitted frame. The minimum required time delay and number of frames before a delay must be inserted depends on the actual bit rate. • 40 kbit/s: At least 35 ms if sending more than 2 frames back-to-back • 100 kbit/s: At least 15 ms if sending more than 2 frames back-to-back

Meter Command Class.description: The Meter Command Class is used to advertise instantaneous and accumulated numerical readings. The Command Class is intended for accumulated values in physical units from a water meter or metering device (gas, electric etc.) and thereby enabling some automatic meter reading capabilities.

Meter Reset Command.description: This command is used to reset the accumulated values stored at the receiving node. If the node advertises support for Meter Reset in the Meter Supported Report Command, the supporting node MUST reset the accumulated values to specific values, instead of setting to zero, when receiving this command. A supporting node MUST ignore this command if it advertises no support for Meter Reset in the Meter Supported Report Command. A supporting node MUST ignore this command if it receives it for a non-supported Meter Type, Rate Type or Scale combination. For fields description, refer to Section 2.2.59.3 Meter Report Command.

Meter Table Configuration Command Class.description: The Meter Table Configuration Command Class defines the Commands necessary to configure the fundamental properties of the meter. The Meter Table configuration commands are separated from the Meter Table monitoring commands in the Meter Table Monitor Command Class, allowing the classes to be optionally supported at different Z-Wave security levels. (E.g. Meter table monitoring commands could be supported in any device, while enabling a strict and certificate based security solution for the Meter Table Configuration Command class). Refer to Section 4 for more details about Z-Wave security.

Meter Table Point Adm Number Set Command.description: This command is used to set the Meter Point Administration Number in the metering device. The Meter Point Administration Number is used to identify the customer.

Meter Table Monitor Command Class.description: The Meter Table Monitor Command Class, version 3 is used for advanced metering applications.
